But Brooks rejected Wilson’s theory that the insertion showed Shakespeare’s maturer style: “an inspired afterthought may come to an author after five minutes just as well as after four years

title: In Marlowe’s Tamburlaine Bajazeth, the captive Turkish emperor, imprisoned in a cage, commits suicide: “He brains himself against the cage.” When his wife Zabina discovers him, “His skul al ruin in twaine, his braines dasht out,” she runs mad, her fi nal speech being in prose, before killing herself as he has done (5.1.305–319). title: The fi rst edition placed them together in the putative overall chronology between Timon of Athens and Macbeth

the Quarto text (“The History of King Lear”) remains in that sequence, but the Folio text (“The Tragedy of King Lear”) is made to follow The Winter’s Tale and precede Cymbeline. The unwary reader is now led to believe that in 1610 Shakespeare went back to Lear, cut out 300 lines from the Quarto, added another 100 lines, and thereby created a new play
